Although it is somewhat out-of-the-way for access to convenient subway lines, it nevertheless has comfortable rooms and a very nice coffee lounge for guests to relax in in they do not wish to stay in their room. It certainly is quiet at night. The furnishing are well maintained and I got a very good rate for a nice room that would have been much more expensive at one of hotels located closer to Tokyo Station or in Roppongi. This hotel provides good value for money. The hotel is exceptionally well-located if one is flying into Haneda Airport as it is a very short taxi ride from the Monorail terminus.

It is a bit out of Tokyo's various centers, but it is close enough by public transport. Near the Yamamoto JR line and two metro stations. And it is a world standard business hotel with spacious rooms on floors 14 to 17, no exciting views, though, but well furnished and amended. Excellent Japanese and Western breakfast buffet. In short: very good option in this price segment.Do not miss the small restaurants just five minutes walking towards Keio University. Good food, nice atmosphere.

We stayed at this property for 6 nights for the Tokyo leg of our family vacation. The location is excellent, being out-of-the-way enough to quietly shut down, but close enough to the Mita, Shibakoen, and Tamachi stations that you can get anywhere you want to go. Breakfast on-site for a family of four was VERY expensive. They had an excellent, expansive buffet of both Japanese and Western fare, which we only partook of twice - and stuffed ourselves. As an alternative, we found the neighborhood just southwest of the property (Shiba5) absolutely packed with fantastic small restaurants and several grocery stores. That neighborhood should be considered an amenity for the hotel. It made it so easy to come back from a day of sightseeing and simply go pick whatever looked delicious. There must be 60 or more small, traditional restaurants in the area. There was even a pizza place that did an excellent job. There is a 7-Eleven for your foreign debit card needs and a good-sized grocery store on Chome that was perfect for loading up on breakfast-in-the-room options. Anyway, the hotel was great. Clean. Quiet. And a great price for what we got relative to the other options. I would highly recommend this property. A totally safe bet that is very well placed. Enjoy.

I was previously impressed by my stay at the Celestine. I was of course curious as to whether they have maintained their standards. I can say that they have and clearly more foreigners have become aware of the value offered by the hotel. If you do book at the Celestine, make sure you fly into Haneda Airport which is closer to the city and not as large as Narita. If you do, getting to the hotel is cheap and quick. Take the monorail, which is a one minute walk once you leave customs, to the end of the line (Hamamatsucho). Trains leave frequently but all trains travel to the same end point. Once at Hamamatsucho, take the JR line one stop to Tamachi station. Total cost was 630 Yen. From the station it is approximately a seven minute walk to the hotel. It took me all of 35 minutes from start to finish. If you simply are loaded down with luggage you can take an airport bus (infrequent) or grab a cab from Hamamatsucho station.The lobby is on the ground floor of an office building with the rooms on the 14th-17th. Be advised that they won't let you check in early. The staff is helpful and all speak serviceable English. The double rooms are comfortable by Tokyo standards. This means small but not tiny as they are in Tokyo hotels of a similar class. The cable TV has some 4 or 5 English language stations for those not fluent in Japanese. Wifi is free and available in the room. The room also comes equipped with an all purpose plug adapter which saved me when I forgot to bring my own. However the best place to work is on the large 14th floor lounge (free wifi) that offers free coffee, tea, mineral water and cookies. There is a garden surrounding the lounge with table where you can enjoy a meal purchased outside the restaurant. The area itself is far from exciting but the subway line is a mere 2 minute walk away as well as the JR line just a 7 minute walk. So it is easy to travel to anywhere in Tokyo. The area also has a web of small, inexpensive restaurants located between the station and Keio University, a short 5 minute walk. The hotel is often discounted and I have managed to snare some very good bargains here.

The hotel is conveniently located in what we can consider 'Greater Tokyo', close to subway and JR stations. As soon as you get into the lobby, you have the chance to experience the order and attention to details so much loved by the Japanese, together with the professionalism and extreme courtesy of staff, who always have a solution for all your needs.The room, and bathroom, quite spacious, are very clean and equipped with everything you could think of. In addition, the room is perfectly insulated and you wouldn't hear any noise, neither from outside nor from other rooms. Great bed, too, both for size and comfort. Pleasant lounge, on the 14th floor, where you can help yourselves with various kinds of teas and coffees.Just to summarize: I would highly recommend it!

Spent 3 nights here, and i have to say it was a lot better than expected. I booked a single room which was quite spacious, and the ammenities provided were more than adequate.The breakfast buffet was rather nice, and the hotel staff were very helpful.All in all it was a perfect stay in a nice hotel, I'll definitely be back to stay there!

my company booked this hotel for me, I didn't have any idea about position and facilities. at the beginning I was a bit disappointed because the hotel doesn't have any swimming pool or gym, and around it looks nothing interesting. but after the first impression I was so happy of Celestine: 5 minutes walking from Mita station, where you can go all around Tokyo in 15 minutes, just 20 minutes walking from Tokyo tower. there is also JR very close and also Tamachi station or Damien just walking distance. during the way to Tamachi or Damien you can find many local restaurants (cheap and simply delicious, with tatami tables as well!) but also shopping malls with western food. the rooms in the hotel are big enough and with a wonderful view of Tokyo; food quality (especially for breakfast) is very high: I was impressed about the freshness and good flavor for any kind of goods. what I like most in the hotel was the lounge at 14th floor (for everybody!!) you can seat drinking free coffee, tea, cappuccino, water...cookies! and a big garden just in front for smoking (smoking restrictions in japan are very strong), very peaceful place! next time to Tokyo, I will go to Celestine!

We have spent three nights in this hotel and our room was quite large, compared to Tokyo standards (though we were three and the added bed took much of the available space).The hotel is located in a business area that is very peaceful even during the week. Few subway stations are at walking distance (5-10 min.). If you plan to visit the city returning to the hotel multiple times I would suggest a more central location (or you will have to walk a lot, the alternative option being to take the Tokyo taxis that are not cheap at all).

Good business hotel.Small room, but large enough, clean, very helpful staff.Excellent soaps and body lotions. You can find in the room anything you want.Great facilities. Good breakfast.Do not seat in caffeteria is extremely expensive, just go around the corner there is a starbucks like coffee shop!

I stayed here recently while on business in Tokyo.The room I got here was a good size and provided all the amenities needed - expect an iron and ironing board but with a quick call to housekeeping this was resolved. The rooms are very clean and comfortable. While I stayed here, something went missing from my room (a complete accident as it was white and blended in with the sheets) - it was accidently sent out with the laundry. The staff where very helpful and managed to have it returned from the company who look after the laundry services. There is a decent choice for breakfast - probably not the best spread that I have ever had considering the price.Overall, the location, cleaniness and staff made the visit a good experience. The hotel is located quite close to a section of laneways that are just full of good restaurants and food - so there is not excuse to get out and enjoy some local cusines!

Have been staying in this hotel for the past few trip to Tokyo and it has never failed nor disappoint me before. It is very easy to get to the hotel with the limousine bus arriving directly at the hotel from Narita airport at only 3100 yen. The hotel room is very clean and comfortable - furnished with all the necessary amenities, toiletries and most importantly, the bed is very comfortable for a good night sleep. Service is excellent with the staff going all the way out to please hotel guest. The location is great with easy access to many food joints, restaurants and convenient stores. Always enjoy returning back to Celestine Hotel whenever I visit Tokyo. Would recommend to anyone who want to stay in a "heavenly" (meaning of Celestine) hotel.

Comfortable, central and Clean. Staff is friendly and helpful. My only issue with the hotel is that after 2230 you can't even get room service which is very inconvenient, especially in a society where working hours are very late. Upside is there are restaurants within walking distance however it is still an inconvenience when it's raining and you get back to the hotel at 2300 and have no desire to go outside again.

I spent one night in the Celestine. The staff is friendly and has very good English language skills and made an effort to accommodate us. We arrived early in the morning and asked if there was a chance for an early check-in. Even though this was not possible without paying for another night, they offered us a room to change. The hotel rooms are spacious (for Japan anyway) and packed with amenities typical for Japan. Very good Continental, American and Japanese breakfast.

I spent several nights in this hotel during my business trip, and felt really good there. The room was medium size, but fully equipped, the room was looking at the hotel terrasse. The stuff was extremely kind and professional. The restaurant was great, nice look at the quiet and clean street, very kind restaurant stuff and quite good mix of japanese and international food. As I saw some comments that there is no restaurants around, I would just like to stress that 2 corners away, close to Mita station, there is a quarter full of nice places to eat.

We stayed here 3 nights and the hotel was very convenient, located in a business district but close to restaurants, 2 different subways and a supermarket. Staf spoke English fairly. A big advantage is if you are flying from/to Narita airport there is a direct line with the train and takes arround 90 min. Take the Asakusa line and the cost is arround 1380 yen.Good for ppl who needs to be arround Minato and is willing to travel a bit (30-40 min) to see the tourist spots like Shinjuku, Roppongi, Shibuya, UenoI would skip the breakfast if you are on holiday and eat at an restaurant

We recently stayed here for 9 nights. There really was nothing that we could be critical about. The location was great being only a couple of minutes walk from two different subway lines. There were quite a few places to eat nearby as well as several convenience stores for extras. Staff at reception spoke English fairly well and were to willing to help us find some obscure locations within Tokyo. Our room was on the 14th floor at the back of the hotel. The room was a lot larger than others we had previously stayed at in Tokyo and elsewhere in Japan. Housekeeping was spotless and could not be faulted. Beds extremely comfortable and curtains blocked the early morning sun if you wanted to sleep in. The rooms were so quiet. Not once did we ever hear any plumbing noises or doors closing in the corridor. Windows were indeed panoramic. To our amazement one morning when the curtains were pulled back, the smog had lifted, and there were crystal clear vistas of Mt Fuji right in front of us. Spectacular on a clear morning. The lounge on the 14th floor was great with free tea, coffee and soda water 24/7. The peaceful gardens located on either side of the lounge were very relaxing after a hectic day of sightseeing. Overall, we thoroughly enjoyed our stay here and would definitely stay here again and would recommend it to others.

We stayed here for 3 nights during our trip to Tokyo. For us the location was convenient - the business district where the hotel is located is nice and quiet, but you can easily get anywhere in the city as public transport works fantastically (and the nearest station "Mita" is only a few minutes away). If you want to have a little stroll in the area, Tokyo Tower is within a walking distance, too. The double room we stayed in was clean, good size with a comfortable bed and a great view of the Rainbow Bridge. Breakfast was ok: quite a good selection of local and western options, but not particularly special in any way. The staff were very friendly, polite and spoke good English. We enjoyed our stay here and would recommend it to anyone who wants to stay in this part of the city - near Roppongi, Odaiba, Ginza etc.

I have stayed here four times already with total duration of more than 6 weeks of stay within the last three years. One thing I like is that it is located just in front of my headquarter office (it is personal's related anyway). Another thing is that this hotel is very consistent with its service. Never even once during my total 6 weeks of stay I have experienced bad thing here. It is clean and all facilities are working fine.Nevertheless, two things are always bugging my mind when I stay here. One is that there is no gym, no pool, nor even sauna to help me getting fit after a long work. Two is that why there is no improvement with the breakfast. It is always beans, bacon, eggs and spaghetti. In the Japanese food corner, it is also always the same miso soup, same variety of pickles, boxes of natto and one among only two kinds of fish. Sometimes I stay in this hotel for about two weeks and having same kind of so-so breakfast becomes an unpleasant thing actually.However, this hotel is still my favorite place to stay in Tamachi area.

The hotel is located in a business district, minato-ku. Nightlife, as well as restaurants and shops, are therefore not immediately close by. It is very well served by the local lines with the station of Mita (5 mins walking distance). Close is also the Daimon station. Apart from the lobby, the hotel is located between the 14th and the 17th floors. I had a single room, but which seemed to be almost a double room. Bed comfortable, good bathroom, great view. Extremely silent. The hotel has a lounge at the 14th floor with a business centre. Using the computer at the business centre may be somehow annoying, the computer works only with 100Y coins, 10 minutes, but if you use the printer, it burns 1 minute each print. The lounge is very relaxing and for whoever needs to smoke, there is an outside patio. Room service ends at 2:20 PM so be sure to switch your "Do Not Disturb" message to "Please make up my room" before that time. Surprisingly, there is no in-room dining and breakfast. We checked in at around 11PM and were frustrated not to have anything to eat. There is a convenience store around the cornier 24/7 but it is a convenience store so is the food sold. Breakfast is quite good and is served until 930 AM. There is also a delicacy shop/bar in the lobby that serves sweets, cakes, pastries, and a few drinks. Free wi-fi anywhere in the hotel. Concierge has been extremely helpful in finding out good spots and providing recommendations. The price has been extremely competitive, booked through booking.com, and it is worth every single yen. There is no gym, no pool... for these amenities, and for full in-room meals you should probably look for a hotel chain or for a more expensive hotel, but this hotel is elegant, extremely clean, extremely good value for money and I will certainly get back there on my next trip in Tokyo.

Stayed here for one night with my husband on our first night in Tokyo. The hotel and its rooms were clean and well appointed. Check-in process was smooth and the staff very polite. The bed was comfortable and the rooms quiet. They rooms weren't huge, but hey...is there such a thing in Tokyo? Definitely more than enough space to move around comfortably, even with two big suitcases set out. I'd say the only drawback to this hotel is the location. There really isn't a ton around. More of a business district than anything. But, the Tokyo subway system is so vast and efficient, this really is not a big deal. You can get anywhere you want in Tokyo fairly easily. They had tea, coffee, and biscuits (cookies) available for free in the lounge. Wish they had regular milk instead of creamer, but again, a minor gripe. Overall, a great experience.

Stayed here for four nights during a business trip. We had a quite good deal given the normal hotel room rate in Tokyo. The hotel has everything you need for a business trip: clean, convenient, and safe. I will probably come back for the next biz trip.Room size is very Tokyo typical, which is cell-like. There is a so-called 24H "lounge", which provides only water (not bottled, from a drinking machine), coffee, and cookies.I'm glad that I didn't choose the package including breakfast. There are tens of options in Tokyo for breakfast, why bother for simple hotel buffet?

We stayed one night in this excellent hotel, near Roppongi to enjoy its nightlife. The location is good, near Tamachi JR line station, and 3 metro stations nearby, which gives a good access to the interesting spots in Tokyo. We did not try the neighbourhood, not sure if there are really interesting stuff to do or eat.The rooms are quite big and clean, with a nice view. They have a very nice lobby and roof garden if you want to relax. It is quite expensive, but this is Tokyo.

I stayed in a superior double room for 5 nights in April 2014.Location: 20-30 min taxi ride from Haneda Airport cost just under $60, 5 minute walk to Mita subway station (Exit 8 or 10) to go to Asakusa via Asakusa line, 10 minute walk to Tamachi station to go to Shibuya or Shinjuku via Yamanote line, 15 minute walk to Hinode station to go to Odaiba via Yurikamone line, business district/quiet area (not much around), hotel lobby leaflet 8x walking distance tourist attractions nearby (including Tokyo Tower and Zozoji temple)Hotel: very clean and new, staff - speak english well, very attentive and helpfulRoom: 21 sq m - smaller than western standards but not too small, requested a room near elevator as not all rooms are close to it, nice view of Tokyo, free wifi, free international newspaper, CNN and BBC on TV, quiet - didn't hear any noise from outside the roomFood: lounge on the 14th floor with free coffee, tea, water and biscuits 24/7, area nearby with lots of restaurants (toward the NEC building) but menus in Japanese only, convenience stores nearby, 3 minute walk to Jonathan's family restaurant (western food) in front of Tokyo Grand Hotel - good and cheap

We stayed here for two nights. It is more of a business hotel ,not many restaurants to walk too. The breakfast was ok.The front desk staff was great and very helpful. The hotel just got changed to a non smoking hotel the day we got there. We were supposed to have a non smoking room but the room smelled like smoke. I asked to change rooms but they couldn't accomodate us the first night. However,we changed rooms the next day but it wasn't any better. To become a non smoking hotel without cleaning drapes, carpets,ect.. doesn't make the smell go away. They have major cleaning to do.

Was there 3nights on business trip, room is clean and refreshing while breakfast is simple but quality on priority. Wifi is available from lobby to lounge (level 14 where u can sip a cup of coffee or tea) and all the way to in room wifi.However there's no nearby restaurant ans the nearest convenient shop doesn't offer much varieties.

was in japan for 10 days and stayed in this hotel as all other hotels were booked out, Stayed in the superior double room.Poor location, not close to the stations,not close to any of the major eating areas or malls.spent alot of time travelling when staying in this hotel.Room it self was presentable, clean. free lounge for guest on the 14th floor which provided coffee, tea and biscuitsI was abit upset at the staff when we requested for a later check-out but there were not flexible about it even though the hotel had enough rooms and wanted me to pay 1000yen more per hour. their reply was it was hotel policy.The previous hotels i stayed in all had no issues with given 1-2hours grace.definitely will not stay here again or recommend this place.

I travel to Japan regularly, and had yet to find a hotel in Tokyo that I would happily return to. Well, I think I have found it. This hotel is very smart, clean, comfortable, and the service is great. WIFI is free, and you get a good connection. In terms of location it is maybe just over 5 minutes walk from Tamachi station, which is on the Yamanote line - a central line that runs through many of the big, central areas of the city. It is a quiet area, which I like, but there is a convenience store within a couple of minutes' walk, and 2/3 restaurants behind the hotel. There are more closer to Tamachi station, and it is a 3-minute train ride to Shinagawa where you are spoilt for choice.

I've stayed at the Celestine a whole bunch of times over the past year or so, for business. The location is good for my business, but the area if pretty quiet otherwise, and stuck between some awkward subway lines that don't seem to intersect handily to get to the usual locations. Beds are comfortable, the lobby is frequented by the usual Japanese hotel luncheon crowd, and the capuccino gets a big tick from me. I've come around to the breakfast - although they've shifted it around lately and it doesn't work as well. Try the Japanese dishes. If you're in need of some nightlife, go out the back of the hotel and head left past the Family Mart and the NEC building and you'll hit the Tamachi 'ginza' area. Blocks and blocks of small bars and izakaya to choose from.

The Celestine met our needs, as vacation travelers spending a few days in Tokyo, perfectly. Our room was a bit smaller than expected, but very clean and with all of the usual amenities. The bathroom had fine Grohe fixtures and the beds were firm and comfortable. The buckwheat pillows available on request are worth getting. The lounge on the 14th floor is an unexpected delight, with books, magazines, free coffee and tea, and a very pleasant atmosphere. There are open patios on either side (smoking and non-smoking) of the lounge that are well protected from the wind (but not rain). Our room was very very quiet - no internal noise from other guests, elevator, etc. and no street noise at all until the work morning was well under way (and even then it was very quiet). Our view included one end of the Rainbow Bridge and the break room at the bank next door. The large picture window in the room provided a lot of natural light. The nearest subway stops are Mita and Shibakoen, both about two very easy blocks away, with Akabenabashi just a few blocks further. It is very easy to get anywhere in Tokyo as these stops are on the Mita and Oedo Lines, which run all around and through the city. At most, you will need to transfer only once to get to just about any location served by the subway or train systems. The buffet in the Grand Cross restaurant was very good, with plenty of Japanese and Western breakfast choices. The hotel and restaurant staff were pleasant and professional. It was easy to get to the Celestine by Keikyu train directly to Mita from Haneda late at night (we landed at around 10 from SFO and made it to the hotel by around 11:30) - the Keikyu trains do not all run directly to Mita and it is necessary to check the maps and information to get the right train. Otherwise it will be necessary to transfer at Sengakuji to the Asakusa line, if I have my info right. All in all, the Celestine was a real good find and an excellent value and we plan on staying there the next time we are in Tokyo.

Good hotel,in great location. Zero night time atmosphere and don't expect any English television. Breakfast really good choices and staff very pleasant. Value for money. If you want a drink after 10.00pm make sure you find the bar at the back of the hotel - I missed it for the first 3 nights !

I stayed here on a business trip. It is a good location, situated conveniently in the heart of Tokyo. The rooms are reasonable, pretty basic. The breakfast was dissapointing so if you can book without. It was very basic, not very inviting, and a very limted choice in a typical basic hotel environment. The staff was lovely, i actually forgot something in the room after i checked out and they were quick to help me find it and keep it for me. I am not a huge gym person, but one time i wanted to go but was told that they do not have a gym.

Enjoyed the stay. Good hotel.2 strange and irritating policies:Extra charge for early arrivals. It happens often when traveling internationally to Japan.But this one is the best: they charged me 4 US dollars for each printed page of my boarding pass. I travel a lot and it never happened to me.To be big, the small things need to be considered. A huge turn off.

I can say that staying at this hotel was a pleasure. It was all clean and working with nice people giving you a warm welcome.I stayed in a single room with all the amenities and had breakfast in the restaurant that has a nice assortment of both western and local foods.People at reception was very helpful for every request.Reaching the hotel is easy because both Mita metro station and Tamachi JR station are close and easily accessible by walk.I would stay here again.

A nice comfortable City hotel. Maybe a bit business orientated but we liked it. Rooms are big enough to spread your bags out in and beds comfortable. Bathrooms have all the usual Japanese innovations. Guest lounge and outdoor area on the 14th floor is a nice touch. Only down side is you are at the end of the shuttle bus circuit. This can give you a free tour of Tokyo if you don't mind spending a couple of hours on the bus getting to Narita airport. City Transport is handy and plenty of good budget eating choices are nearby.

The building has offices up to the 14th floor I believe so all room are located quite high. Very reasonably priced, clean, ask for the rate with breakfast included. public transportation near by, Good option in Tokyo.

Celestine, Minato, is perhaps not the first hotel you think of for a stay in Tokyo, if you are not here for business. BUT, if you, like myself and my hubby appreciate easy access from the "provinces"(train stations), hotel pickup by tour-buses and airport limousine drop-off, then this place might be the one for you. No glizz and glam in the neighborhood around here, but we did find some nice, local food joints.The hotel is quite " A Okej", as far as I am concerned.

We stayed twice in this hotel in our trip to Japan. The big bonus for us, was that the shuttle bus to and from the airport delivers you right in the hotel! We are a big luggages travelers, so the bus was very handy for us, since our 4 luggages would not fit in a taxi! The location was ok, not in the middle of the city buzz, but with 2 stations within walking distance(2 to 5 min walking). Also, they have a good 24hs restaurant, 7eleven, Family Mart nearby! Quiet neighborhood! Rooms are not big, but clean, comfort bed, pillows and the air condition / heater worked perfectly! Free wi-fi.Bathroom was also clean, with shower curtain ( I prefer glass door shower), and all amenities you need!Breakfast was around $15, and you can have Japanese or western options. Well served!Lounge on 14th floor was very cosy with a welcome coffee, water and biscuits! Staff speaks English and always ready to help!

Hotel's location was very good, with excellent transport links (up to three stations within walking distance). I was given a room on a high floor with quite good views. Admittedly, the room was on the small size but then again most Japanese hotel rooms are! However it was very clean - always a good thing! Another positive the buffet breakfast which was quite adequate and the very professional front desk staff. All in all I would recommend Celestine Hotel as a wise choice for a mid-priced hotel in Tokyo - it certainly 'does what it says on the tin'!

Stayed 2 nights on business and found the Celestine to be a great choice in the area. Staff was very friendly and knowledgeable. The location at Mito station provides easy access and multiple options for shopping and dining. Rooms are rather small, but OK with local standards and very clean. Breakfast is fine providing a variety of japanese and western options. Good value.

My fiance and I loved the location. We prefer a quiet home base to return to, an easy way to get there (2 subway stations nearby), and a smattering of liveliness within walking distance (Tokyo tower and a "restaurant row" within a couple of street blocks). Once inside the hotel, you will immediately see the hotel is modern, updated and impeccably clean. Perhaps it wasn't the right time of the year (Octobor), but we didn't come across any kids in the hotel -- the clientele seemed primarily to consist of businessmen and some tourists. This is a big plus for those who appreciate tranquility, as we do.The hotel rooms, while small (but not by Tokyo standards), are clean and updated. We didn't see faded carpets or dinged up furniture that you sometimes get in older, bigger hotels that rely on their brand recognition. The AC/thermostat was modern (giving you the ability to set the temperature once and forget about it), and the hotel includes fast wifi on the premises.The front desk reception / concierge staff was very helpful with excellent English skills and they helped us with all sorts of requests, from locating a laundromat to finding a good shabu shabu restaurant. The one service oddity we experienced was when we asked for help finding something to eat late our first night in, the front desk staff didn't tell us there was a street consisting of probably 30-50 restaurants just a couple of blocks away and instead directed us to a place about 20 minutes away with only 3-5 choices (mostly izakaya with terrible food).. we had to discover the restaurant area on our own a couple of days later.The gem of our stay which we really enjoyed was the hotel lounge, which I believe is on the 14th floor. It consists of a beautiful and large "living room" like the kind you might expect in a boutique ski resort -- this was the perfect place to bring a newspaper or laptop and catch up on email or read the daily news. They have a nice coffee machine there that makes good cappuccino/expresso (free). Immediately outside this lounge was a large outdoor patio area that I found to be ideal for smoking my cigars and getting in the vacation mood.In all, we enjoyed the hotel's cleanliness, excellent service, convenient and safe location, and the surprisingly enjoyable lounge. I highly recommend this hotel and would stay here again in a heartbeat!

We stayed in this hotel from 28-31 December for 3 nights, We booked a superior double non smoking and we were assigned room 1734 where we could get a partial view of the rainbow bridge and Fuji TV station. The hotel is shared with an office building and rooms are from level 14 onwards. What I liked about this hotel?1.The superior double is spacious enough for 2 ladies with 2 huge luggages and a lot of shopping bags. Do not book the smaller rooms. It comes with complementary toiletries of great quality. (Kose after shave for men, Mikimoto cosmetics, etc...)2. It is located 30 minutes by car from Haneda airport, 10 minutes away from Tsukiji and Ginza. The nearest metro station are Mita station which is a 5 mins walk and Tamachi Station which is 10 mins away. Tamachi links directly to Shibuya and Shinjuku.3. Level 14 provides complementary drinks (Tea, Coffee machine with Cappuccino and Water Dispenser) for 24 hours. There is an ice dispenser located on your room level and a vending machine as well.4. Wi-fi is available for free through out the hotel, which is not common for Japanese hotels5. Service staff spoke great english. They were very helpful when we did a late check in, early check out at 4am and in providing directions and assistance in making reservations to places that we needed help onWhat I did not like about this hotel1. Breakfast did not come cheap. However, after reading reviews on the breakfast, we did not pay for breakfast.2, The corridors is very long. We need to walk around 2-3 lanes in order to reach the elevator3. There is no food around the hotel as this is located in the business district. There is a convenient store located about 2 mins away and food is nearer to the train stations.Apart from that, I do love this hotel for the accessibility and great service staff. If you are looking to stay somewhere near Ginza, Odaiba and Tsukiji, this would be a great place.

If you need to be in this part of Tokyo, this hotel is a very good base. For a start the room was a decent size, bed very comfortable, bathroom very reasonable for Tokyo standards, internet excellent and free. Lounge on 14th floor is an added bonus. breakfast buffet was very pretty decent for 1,500 yen. Service generally seemed fine. There is a nice Italian restaurant on the ground floor at the back of the hotel which I only found on the last of my 5 nights!! 3 minute walk to subway. Other restaurants, shops etc about 10 minutes walk away.

Staying at the hotel at the moment lovely rooms and great staff but the roomservice is horrible, it only starts at 3pm so no posibilities to get breakfast in the hotelroom. Also the bar closes at 10.30 pm so no drinks availible after that time. Only in the minibar at the room wich has a very limited choice of drinks only water, beer and appletizer (no coca cola, iced tea or sprite )

We stayed here on a family holiday in October and had booked 3 rooms, that were nice but the rest of the hotel guests were business people, location was nice, down the road was a nice temple and bakery, it was a great location to walk around. Breakfast was not that great. But the hotel staff arranged for our transfer to the airport and luckily arranged for an extra night's stay on short notice when our flight got delayed with the weather in October. The Hotel is situated beside a lot of aircraft leasing companies. Only 3 minutes walk to the nearest metro station and 10 minute walk to the JR line station. No swimming pool.

I remember this place, because some time ago I've been bumping onto a bunch of positive reviews about this hotel online, telling me how hip and cool this hotel is. The Expedia and Orbitz users have rated this place 4.5 stars. Now, I travel to Tokyo on a regular bases (5 - 7 times per year or so) and always try to discover new locations and options, so this time I've decided to try out Celestine.The location is not bad. Rooms are also not bad and quite spacious by Tokyo standards. However, after 10:00 the hotel is dead. Nothing works - the room service operates only until then, after that, good luck to you. The bar and the restaurant are closed on Saturdays and Sundays. This is highly disappointing, because if management thinks treating the hotel facilities to their own convenience is an acceptable thing to do, then they are clearly in the wrong business. Anyway, there is nothing cool or trendy here, it's just a hotel. If the location is convenient, go ahead and book it - it's not bad. But do not go out of the way to stay here, there are plenty of other similar hotels in this price category all around Tokyo.

The hotel was clean and efficient, and there are some interesting areas within walking distance, but if you are visiting Tokyo for anything other than business, I would not recommend it. We paid for breakfast, and it was one of the cheapest layouts I have ever seen. The had powdered eggs, made from a box, french fries and hot dogs for breakfast, it never changed.

We had a nice reasonably sized room with a superb view of the bay area. It was just amazing to watch the lights from the distant buildings in the evening and the shades of the sunrise in the mornings. The room was well equipped and clean. Unfortunately smoking currently is still allowed in some areas and one in our party had a room which reeked of cigarette smoke. He requested for change and was given a different room the next day. The hotel is located in a quiet business district but the subway station is just around the corner and some nice eateries less than 10 minutes walk away. There is a limousine bus to and from the airport which added to its convenience. The personnel at the reception were attentive though they were at times somewhat aloof. Overall a great place. Oh, they have a 24 hour café bar where you could help yourself to some coffee/tea after a long day in the city.

I selected this hotel for my first business trip to Japan as the location was good, near several train stations and also a quick taxi journey to and from Tokyo city centre.The checking in process was easy and painlessThe lobby was very nice and grand as you would expect featuring a small cafe/ coffee bar on the right hand side serving nice Coffee's and light snacksHowever the Food menu and quality of food was average, The first room on the 14 floor, was a standard room and it was very clean but very small,I decided to upgrade for a bigger room the following night which wasn't as bad Floor 16 - at least in this one you had a place to put your case without banging into it every morning.The internet was extremely fast and had a open area on the 14 floor (if i can remember) which was served free drinks and biscuits etc.The early morning Bus service to the airport was very efficient and the hotel even offered Coffee to take away with a cereal bar for your journey - nice touchI would stay here again for sure

Celestine hotel is situated in Tokyo, in the business district as well as close to some city amenities (Tokyo tower, Roppongi Hills commercial area, etc.). There are also some nice restaurants 2 blocks away. Metro station is less than 5 minutes walk away.The room is well equiped with a comfortable size (compared to some other Tokyo hotels) and provides you lots of services and amenities (including internet connection).Breakfast consists of a buffet (japanish style) and is served in a separated place on the ground floor. Service is outstanding.I recommend this hotel for business and leisure travellers to Tokyo.

I spent a week at the Celestine hotel and had a great experience. The rooms are comfortable and not too small per Tokyo standards. The amenities are good as well.The room service menu is limited, and the breakfast can get old after a few days. However, the hotel is walking distance to a bunch of coffee shops, convenience stores and restaurants.The hotel is also located between 2-3 train stations that are about a 5-10 mins walk away. Very helpful if you're interested in looking around Tokyo.

As some others have said this is a business hotel primarily but a reasonable value option for the non business traveller. Staff: excellent, helpful and courteous. No sign of the alleged rudeness one other reviewer mentioned. Communication was not a problem but then I don't expect everybody to speak English (again as some reviewers seemed to). We had no problems being understood. Rooms: size ok remembering this is Tokyo. Clean, tidy and well organised. Bathroom not massive but acceptable and shower (over bath) was great. Good free products in the room. I found the towels (mentioned by others as a bit thin) ok - not the best we had in Japan but not the worst. Amenities: a cafe, restaurant and nice shared lounge area are about it. All seem good thoughView: from our 16th floor window - fabulous!!!Location: cheapskates like me should walk to Tamachi station where the JR pass can be used - it's also a bit livelier down there than round the hotel. A number of metro stations around if you feel the need. We found it a good base for seeing Tokyo. All in all a good solid choice.

The Celestine is well located in the business district, a stones throw from the metro, Tokyo Tower just round the corner and a plethora of places to eat less than 10 minutes walking distance away.The staff are super attentive and efficient.The rooms are compact, but more than spacious enough. The hotel is very quiet and offers a good nights rest. The curtains were excellent for blocking out the morning light.Breakfast is a mixed bag of Japanese and 'Western' foods.The highlight is the lounge on the 14th floor for taking tea / coffee.

I travel a lot for business and this is one of the best business hotels I stayed in. I arrived pretty late (mid night) and the staff is very attentive to check me in. The room is very neat and clean, surprisingly spacious (hotels in Tokyo is normally very cramped). There are convenient stores nearby so buying drinks and snacks is easy.

This hotel excels in customer service. My room was really nice. Not spacious, but I wasn't spending my days in there. Bed was perfect. Wonderful view of the city. Nice peaceful courtyard on the 14th floor, with a lounge/library with free coffee, tea and yummy biscuits (cookies). The staff are all professional and hard working. Great location and in a quiet part of town. You can't go wrong staying here.

The room had just enough space for 2 people to share. I really liked the toiletries they provided. The shampoo and shower gel were in large containers. Since we stayed at the hotel for over a week, it was convenient not having to use the usual small ones. The room and the bathroom were always spotlessly clean.We loved their lounge area. It was very cozy and homey. There were books and magazines available for you to read plus cookies and coffee/tea too. It was nice hanging out at their lounge after dinner. Their buffet breakfast was also good, it had a lot of variety. There were Japanese, American and European dishes available to choose from.The staff was always friendly and gracious -- from reception to housekeeping up to the waiters at breakfast service.We recommend this hotel if you like a nice and quiet vacation in Tokyo.

The hotel is located in the CBD and is therefore aimed at business people. Staff are very polite, rooms are small, but kept impeccably clean. The hotel bar is warm and well stocked, but the adjoining restaurant is not particularly welcoming and food is average. There are plenty of good Japanese restaurants all within walking distance, and attractions such as the Tokyo Tower, Emperor's Palace and the Ginza shopping area etc are within a 10-40 minute walk, or closer if the metro is taken.

I visited this property recently to participate in a conference. The hotel consists of a lobby and four floors (14-17) of a commercial building. One of the restaurants does a double duty as the breakfast restaurant, but the lobby also has a relatively large cafeteria. The standard are quite small, but this is Tokyo. Bed is comfortable, and AC easy to adjust. Bathroom is perhaps a bit too small, the door opens inwards almost to the bathtub. Service was generally good, although some of the junior staff were not perfectly fluent in English. Their attitude was excellent, of course. The hotel has a very nice lounge on the 14th floor, which is actually a small building on a courtyard inside the building. The lounge has sofas, chairs and tables for just, well, lounging around. It only serves coffee and tea, though. One can smoke on the other side of the courtyard, and the free lounge wifi covers courtyard as well.

This is a business hotel and the 2nd time I am staying here. The 1st time was 2 years ago and I have to say that I saw vast improvement in the service and facilities. Now there is WIFI available in the entire hotel and the signal access is very strong and connectivity very fast. It's very easy access from Haneda Airport ~ 24 minutes via train to Mita station and about a 3 min walk from the station to the hotel. The hotel is very clean well maintained. The rooms are certainly not as large as some of the large chain hotels in Shinjuku area but more than adequate for business travellers. The buffet breakfast has both Western and Japanese fare and is good value.There is a free lounge on the 14th floor with free coffee/tea/biscuits and opens to a roof top garden. There are also 2 large stations < 10 minutes walk Mita/Tamachi that will give you good access to anywhere in Tokyo you want to go. Very nice restaurants just behind the hotel so if you are too lazy to venture far for food, they are good options to try out. With 10-15 minutes walk you can get to Zojoji, Tokyo Tower and Shibakoen.It's a quiet hotel and perfect for business travellers.

It´s important to begin by saying that it´s a business hotel. If you´re looking for a hotel close to sightseeing and transportation go to somewhere else.Celestine Hotel is a very nice hotel if you´re on business. The lobby is amazing. Spacious, clean, high roof and with a big reception center. Perfect.Some of the male receptionists are rude. I suppose they are used to dealing with businessmen and they don´t like backpackers... The female receptionists are wonderful.Our room was spacious and with a lovely view of the city.Wi-fi is for free, and it´s very fast.It´s a good detail that they have a lounge on the 14th floor with free cofee, tea, water, 24 hours.Excellent cleaning staff.It´s 5 minutes from Mita subway. It´s not an important station, you´ll need to make transfer lines if you want to go to the city center (Shibuya, Roponggi).There´s a railway station 10 minutes away, Tamachi. It´s a minor station, you´ll need to transfer lines to go to the center, airport or shinkasen stations.In conclusion, a very good hotel if you´re working and your company pays for your taxis.

Nice hotel...easy access from haneda airport and to see tokyo...free coffee in lounge after a day of sightseeing....free wifi thoroughout the hotel a great bonus....rooms were clean and a good size...

Our room was the deluxe corner twin (which is 2 full size beds). The room was huge, the bathroom luxurious. Highly recommend this room which has windows the length of the room. This a beatiful hotel, it's close to 2 metro stops, and there are nearby restaurants. We would definitely stay here again.

This hotel is in a good location in Minato. It is a walking distance from two train stations, and you can get to many parts of Tokyo easily from it. The rooms are clean, beds are comfortable, and guests are provided with many nice beauty care products. For some reason, I noticed that some Tokyo hotels did not provide any body lotions but this one provided three different types of lotion including a small body oil. In my opinion, the customer service is okay, but needs improvement. It was not consistently good. Depending on which staff was assisting me, it could be good or bad. One example, is that I needed information and directions, and the two staff members seemed too impatient to assist me. I felt like I was bothering them.That was the only negative because I still had a good stay in this hotel.

review_body: The Celestine Hotel was a great find in Tokyo - a city we've been to many times! I wanted a room that was a decent size as there were two of us in the room (and Japanese hotel rooms are notoriously small) and it certainly was a good size for Japan and the bathroom was a good size as well - with a nice long bench to put toiletries. Some of the good features in the bathroom were a nice bath (shower over the bath), very large size shampoos/conditioners etc and they also had a very well-stocked amenity box with everything you could want. The only thing that wasn't ideal were the very thin towels which were scratchy - not sure why they skimped on the towels. The room had a comfortable bed, dressing gowns were provided and there were also a couple of sofa chairs, a reasonable sized desk, wardrobe and safe plus tea/coffee making facilities. There was no iron and ironing board but that was brought up to the room very quickly when ordered.The hotel has a nice lobby with a cafe in it. The Celestine Hotel is in a business area (a block from NEC headquarters) but there isn't too much around the area. However within the same building as the hotel there are several restaurants and we went to the Italian restaurant Pagliacci Due which was great! There is also a Tully's coffee shop (great coffee) within the building as well so it's convenient if you want a restaurants close by. Also the Shibakoen train station (on the Toei Mita line) is just a couple of minutes walk away and you can get anywhere in Tokyo once on the subway system. There are other stations also nearby but Shibakoen is the closest. Also staff are great at the hotel and their English skills are generally pretty goodInternet is free in the rooms (but you can upgrade to a higher speed if you want but this wasn't necessary for normal business usage). TV in the rooms has BBC and CNN so a couple of English channels. Our package didn't include breakfast but they did provide a discount off the breakfast but we still had to pay 1500 yen each person. The breakfast was OK but the buffet doesn't change from day to day so you'd probably get pretty sick of it after a few days but all the basics are provided. There is also a guest lounge that is available to all guests but we were busy and didn't get to use it!As a business hotel, it was ideal and we would stay there again. We booked the hotel directly (as it was the same price as my usual booking site for Asia, Agoda). Beware of the very strange entry on your credit card - the name of the hotel appeared as gobbledygook (so I'm guessing it was in Japanese) but the location says France (I guess it's a French owned hotel) - it took a while to figure out it was the hotel charge on my card! I paid about US160 per night inc. all taxes and service fees for a Deluxe Double. The Celestine Hotel enjoys a good reputation in Japan so I think overall it was one of the better places we've stayed and I consider it very good value for money.

The location of Celestine Hotel is quite convenient if you need to be close to the Tokyo Metro. Just a few minutes walk to the Shibakoen station on the Hibiya line and a Tully's Coffee shop and some restaurants are downstairs in the same building. We recommend the little Italian place for a nice casual dinner! The rooms are spacious - a luxury by most Tokyo standard - despite the reasonable rates. Internet is included which is now something I watch for on every stay - it should be free. There is a charge if you want step up to high speed internet - but that's seems only necessary if you plan to download movies or large amounts of streaming data. We were very happy with the rate of the free wireless internet for all email and even uploading photos to Facebook.The breakfast charges are very confusing. On-line when booking direct it says "breakfast included" but when you check-in they give you a "discount voucher" for 1500 yen. When you go to use them you find is is not really 1500 yen off the breakfast but the voucher gives you a discount from full breakfast price of 2100 yen to 1500 yen! So what we thought was breakfast included still cost us 3000 yen each morning for two of us. And the breakfast was very basic - rather poor selection and very budget hotel in buffet presentation. Trying to get an explanation of the breakfast charges compared to the "breakfast included" booking from the front desk at check-out was impossible, so we just figured it out ourselves, paid and accepted it. However - the nice rooms and generally good service certainly compensated for the small breakfast fiasco so we would stay again.

A 10 day stay at the Celestine Hotel provided a wonderful base to go and see some of the wonderful sights of Tokyo. We didn't even scratch the surface with what we visited.The hotel was situated in a quiet area - despite being a main street. The rooms were clean, and cleaned daily. Comfortable bed and room in general. Rooms are a bit small for a 4 star hotel, however travellers must remember this is normal for Japan, and in no way detracted from our stay. A very varied selection of cooked and buffet breakfast foods.My favourite little experience was the sound of birdsong which was piped throughout the hotel in the morning. Later in the day wonderful aromatic aromas wafted throughout the hotel.So much to see and do in Tokyo. We visited Tokyo Tower, Disney Tokyo, Hachiko's statue, and also took day trips to Mount Fuji, and Nikko. We saw temples and shrines, gardens and so much more. Also spent some time in Harajuku and other shopping areas. Another holiday could be done with to recover!!!! We will return to other parts of Japan in the future.

We stayed in this hotel for two nights in May 2013.The hotel is not located in a touristic area, but it's really close to the metro station, so moving around Tokyo is quite easy if you choose to sleep here.The staff speaks fluent English and can help you, in case you need it.The room and the bathroom were spotless clean, and the bed with all its pillows were really comfy. In the room, there is a sort of iron press to iron your clothes and a line in the bathroom to hang the wet ones.On the 14th floor there is a lounge were you can help yourself with coffee, tea, cappuccino, water and relax. Wi-Fi is free both in the lounge and in the room.We asked for a fitness center in the hotel, but were told that they have one, but it's closed on Monday and Tuesday (the days of our staying there), so I cannot tell how it looks like.

We stayed here for 4 nights during golden week, room only. This is a really nice hotel. We had a standard double room which was a little small but perfectly adequate for what we needed... a room to sleep in! Spotlessly clean and very well kept, there were no issues with things being broken etc. We stayed on the 17th floor, room 1752 which had an amazing view over the city, and we were greeted with a fantastic view of Mt Fuji on 2 mornings. Quite special as friends of ours have been to Japan for longer than us and never glimpsed it. We didn't have breakfast so can't comment on this. We ate out instead, grabbing pastries and tofu skin rice wraps (sound gross, taste awesome!). There is a 7/11 and a Family Mart a very short walk away. The lounge on the 14th floor is great with free tea and coffee and little coffee buscuits. Very nice touch. There are tea/coffee making facilities in the room too. The hotel is located close to 4 stations... the ones we used the most were Akabanebashi (about 10 min walk) to Shinjuku/Harajuku/Shibuya; Tamachi (for the JR line, about a 7 min walk). We used Mita station a couple of times and didn't use Shibakoen at all. The staff were incredibly friendly and helpful, making dinner reservations for us at other restaurants and showing us local places to eat that have english menus. No issues whatsoever. They knew it was my birthday too and when we arrived I had a card and small gift in the room waiting for me :) Very nice touch. Overall I would recommend this hotel... it may be a little out of the way, but it's so nice to leave the chaos of places like Shinjuku, Harajuku and Akihabara and return to the peace and quiet of Minato. And actually it's quite well placed to get to all of these places, being kind of in the middle. I would stay here again in a heartbeat.

Hotel is easy to catch by train (subway), when arriving in Narita airport. Hotel stuff is friendly and service is great. Rooms are clean and the view from 16th floor is great. Breakfast is served in both western and Japanese style for same price. To mention one thing, celestine blend coffee is great! Location is great, while it is so easy to travel all over the Tokyo by subway. One minus is that free WLAN is not available on rooms but you can use it on celestine lounge.

We stayed here for six nights whilst in Tokyo and would thoroughly recommend the hotel for a visit to this great city. I required assistance as had lost my mobile phone and the staff on the front desk could not have been more helpful. They spoke with the lost property staff at Japan Rail and with their assistance reunited me with my property. The room that we stayed in was on the 17th floor and had breathtaking views over the cityThe hotel was close to MIta subway station and a shortt stroll from Tokyo Tower and some great restaurants and coffee shops.We paid for a room only and visited various coffee shops for breakfast On our last day we thought we would pay the discounted price and try the hotels breakfast.. We wished we had not. The breakfast buffet was pretty poor with the hot food served at luke warm temperatures. This was the only negative aspect of our stay and we wished we had stuck to the Hotels coffee shop in the foyer as that would have been much better than the hot breakfast in the restaurant Breakfast aside could not find fault with any other area of the hotel and would recommend to anyone wishing to stay close but not amongst the hustle and bustle of the city

This is a very popular business hotel. The layout is relaxing, the staff is wonderful. The rooms are small but clean. Love the Celestine blend coffee. The bar is quiet but well stocked in the evening, and the buffet breakfast is very nice in the morning (if you like your eggs well done though you should politely ask them to prepare for you special). It's a short taxi ride (@1600yen) from Tokyo station, and shorter from Shinagawa station (@1200 yen) where you can arrive or depart on the NEXX from NRT. Tamachi station is walking distance. A very nice part of the hotel is that - even though it has no fitness facilities of its own - it is pleasant 10min walk from the Minato City sports center - even has a 6 lane 25m lap pool -nice but be prepared to share! Note that you cannot wear your outside shoes into the fitness center. Carry your gym shoes.
