review_body: This is a very nice hotel. Very comfortable and very conveniently located to explore Tokyo. The breakfast selection is really good and the service impeccable. The views from the hotel room were really nice and the room was good size and very clean. I also enjoyed the selection of amenities in the room. I would have preferred if it had a small gym or an agreement with some local gym. Even so, I would not hesitate in staying there if I am lucky enough to visit Tokyo again. Very close to the hotel (close to Keio University) there are many nice places to eat out. It is also worth mentioning that the hotel is in a business building, where there is also a sushi house, a pizzeria and a Chinese restaurant.On my last day, I had a traditional green tea with a very nice Japanese sweet in the pastisserie in the lobby. I really enjoyed that too.

Stayed for one night during business trip. The hotel lobby is quite attractive, rooms are on 14th floor up. Rather small and functional rooms, but everything does its job, and the rooms are ilean and well maintained. Wifi was free and the TV had at least BBC and CNN. Due to short stay did not try the lounge, but looks quite inviting.Breakfast (USD 15) is something to skip - rather try to find a Starbucks.Can imagine to stay again if travelling without family (as rooms are too small).

I accidentally ran across this hotel while making reservations in Tokyo.The location is kin of random, but it turned out to be excellent. Here are the main points:1. The location is central enough, but quiet. It is still convenient enough o get anywhere you want with several subway station from 2 to 10 min walk, and Tamachi JR station about 8 min walk. 2. Rooms are certainly on a small size, but large enough to sleep and be around, bathroom is very nice and clean.3. Bed is very nice :).4. The lounge with free coffee drinks and tea, and cookies was very nice and have ben used by us all the time.if I am in Tokyo again, I will not stay anywhere else.

It is a very well known hotel that the limousine bus from the terminal can drop you at the lobby.Positive:-decent stay - room cleanliness/ comfort- nice staffNegatives:- location is far for tourists/ good for business travelers as it is located in Roppongi which is a business hub- poor breakfast (not free)- limited english speaking staff but this is fine, you can still get to communicate with some patienceAll in all, this hotel is great for business travelers due to its location in the business hub. It is hectic for tourists as you need to jump on the train every time you want to go somewhere or take a taxi which is too expensive. I recommend those visiting for leisure to stay in the Ginza area which is a premium shopping district, similar to fifth avenue and champs élysées. You will at least find a restaurant open after 12am.

This is a surprising hotel in a relatively quiet area but close to train stations, Keio University and the Tokyo Tower. The layout of the hotel is pleasing and the rooms for Tokyo are of a reasonable size. The lounge on the 14th floor with free tea, coffee and biscuits is a lovely idea and a good place to relax in the morning. Service is good at the usual high Japanese order. The hotel is not far from Haneda Airport and if you take the monorail and then a taxi can be there in about 30 minutes for approximately 1600 Yen. For the price it is a real Tokyo bargain.

We enjoyed our 3 days stay at Celestine hotel very much!The rooms are modern and relatively spacious for Japanese standards.Choose a room on the west side for a phantastic view.English newspaper is supplied every morning.JR Yamanote line ("Tamachi" station, west exit) is in 7min walking distance - which is great for JR pass holders, "Mita" station (Toei line) is even closer and just 300m away.

My friend and i recently were guests at this wonderful hotel for four nights last week. Although we spend less of our time in our rooms, i've got to say the staffs here are very warm, welcoming and very polite. They helped us with directions to different parts of tokyo with a smile. You can know that the staffs and the citizens of Tokyo are polite and their service came from their heart.Rooms were a bit small for standard room, however it was clean and homely. We were pleasantly surprised on one of our days where we left our messy room and came back to a VERY NEAT AND TIDY room where our toiletries, make ups and other beauty products were arrange neatly in heights and sizes. This hotel is located slightly away from the busy and colourful areas like Shinjuku and Shibuya so its quiet and peaceful at night. But its less than 5 minutes walk from Mita station. If you like to party, a 10-15mins taxi ride to Roppongi's night life cost less than US15 (taxis in tokyo are very expensive.)If there was one small thing the hotel was missing is definitely a swimming pool. I personally like to take a dip in every hotel's swimming pool when i am on vacation. But a short walk to the beautiful Tokyo Tower at night would makes you forget about swimming.Overall, i had a comfortable stay at the hotel and wished i could stay longer.Special thank you to Shibata and the rest of the front desk staffs. Missing you guys and Tokyo. already.

This hotel is in an excellent location - very close to two subway stations (one or two minutes from Shibakoen Station, and three or four minutes from Mita Station - both on the Mita Line of the Toei Subway. There are several historic sites nearby as well - Zojyoji Temple and Shiba Toshogu Shrine. And the famous Tokyo Tower is a short walk from the hotel as well. There is a great area near Mita Station and NEC's offices that has many restaurants and a convenience store. You can find many different kinds of Japanese cuisine in this neighborhood, which is only a few minutes walk from the hotel. And there is a Tully's Coffee in the building.The rooms are spotless, although a little on the small side, and very quiet. The wireless Internet is free. The TV has a few English-speaking stations - CNN International, BBC World and a movie channel that shows American movies with Japanese subtitles. I have had rooms on both the city and bay side of the hotel, and both have great views. Another hotel perk is the 14th floor lounge that has both indoor and outdoor seating. The outdoor lounge area is Spanish-feeling - it has several tables and chairs in a beautiful setting with Spanish tile. The lounge has coffee and tea available most of the day.The breakfast seems to be priced differently depending on your room rate (it is typically not included in the room rate). My breakfast price was 1500 yen, and it was well worth it. It has Japanese breakfast items including fish which is different every day, salad with a variety of dressings, and noodles and vegetables, American/Western breakfast items (pastries and bread, eggs and bacon) and fruit, yogurt, cereals, juices and coffee.The service is excellent here - staff are very friendly and helpful. I highly recommend this hotel!

Very good hotel at a very good location. Also value for money. Gym / pool would be nice but one can walk in the nearby park offers place for excercise. Plenty of authentic places nearby and the tube which is very close is in Ginza in just a couple of minutes.

Good service, awesome concierge, metro station(s) nearby, room clean and calm but slightly too small, big nice breakfast buffet (but exactly the same every day), a lot of small restaurants nearby, stayed here over new-year 12/13. value for money ok. only setback (the semi-double room is definitly too small for two people).

Stayed here on a Saturday night and was pleasantly surprised. It's located not too far from Tokyo Tower and as such I asked if the hotel staff would mind placing us in a room with a view. We got what we asked for with a partial view of Tokyo Tower and a beautifully clear view of Mount Fuji in the distance. Room size was pretty big by Japanese standards with a nice sized bath. The buffet breakfast was filling and offered a large selection of both Japanese and Western food.What I liked most about this place was the 14th floor. There is a communal lounge with a library which opens up onto a roof top surrounded by the 15-17th floors. So there's a totally private square/garden area with tables and chairs in which to enjoy free condiments and have a read. Free wifi too!Saw the Japanese hammer thrower Murafushi at breakfast too!

Great hotel and location in Tokyo. Stayed there for business several times and have had a very pleasant experience every time. Nice modern rooms, large European/Asian/American style breakfast, and super-friendly staff. Walking distance to all major subway lines, temples, Tokyo Tower, etc. etc.

This hotel is perfect, especially for business trips. It is right in the middle of the business district. Staff is waiting outside to help you with your lugage. There is Wifi throughout the hotel, and there are some lounges on some floors where you can relax, have some coffee or just sit and talk.The staff's English is OK, but not perfect but don't expect it to be anywhere in Japan. Little priecy but same for all hotels in Japan, for everything basically if you are used to European standards.

What a great hotel! I had to travel to Tokyo with a mind to keep costs under control so was forced away from the usual 4/5* or quaint/boutique/design hotels I try to stay in usually when I travel. I found Celestine through doing a bit of research online and thought I'd give it a go. Given the low price relative to competition, I had some concerns that it would not be great, even with all the good tripadvisor reviews. I was delighted to be proven wrong!I got the Superior Double Room, which is one of their smaller doubles. The room is indeed small, but not uncomfortably so - there is a good sized king bed, a desk with just about enough space to work and they have even managed to include a small sofa and coffee table. Wardrobe space is limited, so perhaps not the best place for an extended stay. I was impressed with the finish of the room. The hotel has clearly been recently renovated and everything looks pristine and modern. Also impressed with the attention to detail, for example in providing bathrobes and an excellent selection of toiletries, useful to a light-traveler like myself with carry-on bags only. As an added bonus, the hotel has a 24-hour convenience store at the back that sells drinks, light snacks etc. Last but in no way least, all the staff speak perfect English and are very nice and helpful.The downside? The area is not the most happening and you'll need to take public transport in the day and some taxis to get back home late at night and the latter will add to the total bill. Still, the price difference from anything remotely similar in, say, Roppongi, will more than offset this outlay. The hotel would also benefit a lot if management could strike a deal with a nearby gym for guest use. Finally, it would be great if in addition to the Japanese channels the TV had a few international ones, if only news-channels to keep up to date with what is happening. If the latter two points were addressed, this place would get 5 out of 5 for me.

I found this hotel several years ago and stay there each time I visit Tokyo. It is the top 4 floors of an office building. The staff are really helpful, breakfast which I usually take is also good value for money and quite an extensive buffet for Tokyo. Free hi speed internet is a real bonus and very helpful for when doing business. It is centrally located close to Toei Mita Line, Shiba Park station and also very close to the Monorail heading out to Haneda Airport. Being not so old the list of amenities in each room is impressive, I usually get a double deluxe room which I find spacious enough when either I or with my wife are in Tokyo. The price is also very reasonable.

I have have stayed in this hotel couple of times and is my best experience so far in Tokyo. The hotel's lobby, rooms etc. are really not intimidatingly small. Although on one occasion, i booked the room thru my local office who got me very good deal but turned out the room was quite small and without a couch.Best thing I like about this hotel is a nice restaurant, quite neighborhood and proximity to Central Tokyo locaitons. I do not mind walking a kilometer or so (when not raining), so it is perfect if you are looking for business class clean and nice hotel.

I stayed at Celestine Hotel for a business trip in September. The staff there were extremely polite and helpful. I was also very impressed by the food and services for breakfast in the restaurant. There were great selections for both traditional Japanese and western style breakfast. Free high-speed WiFi access was another bonus. The room was very clean and comfortable. Overall, it was a very pleasant stay for a business trip. Highly recommended for a business trip in Tokyo.

I typically stay at higher class hotels in Tokyo, but had to get here for city overbooking. THe Celestine is not the fanciest hotel, Pool and Gym are absent, but rooms lack nothing compared to those I go to in 5 stars hotels (especially amenities). There's a fine lounge and personell is kind, with good, very good English (also the cleaning team, I found out).The GrandRock restaurant deserves a special mention. Nice architecture, some less fancy details, but the chef displays excellent european selection. It's not the busiest in town, probably, but this restaurant deserves high ranking for food, dressings and service. I rarely am surprised by what is offered, but here I had two fully regenerating dinners.To sum up: not the fanciest, but a safe, decent well located option.

Celestine is a top 4* hotel (don't expect 5* facilities). I was positively impressed as I ended up there- sceptical - during the busy IMF week and our usual corporate hotels were full.Good location, Nice lobby, friendly staff, nice well equipped room with decent size for Tokyo standards. The bed was comfy, the view through the big windows very nice. I had north east facing and could see the Tokyo tower.There is free wifi across.Highlight: there is special filter coffee package available something I haven't see elsewhere.Only downside? There are not linked with any frequent flyer programm.I did not try breakfast.

My husband and I stayed at Celestine Hotel for 4 nights while we were in Tokyo. The hotel is a short walk from Toei Shibakoen Station, as well as Mita Station (exit A10 / A8) which has both Mita Line and Asakusa Line. Hotel staff spoke reasonable English, and were all very helpful. Their breakfast buffet was excellent both in terms of quality and choices!!!To save some transportation costs, my husband and I bought the 1-way Airport Limousine tickets with Tokyo Metro 1-day Passes (promotional price, about 400-600 yen off the full price). The Airport Limousine dropped us off very conveniently in front of the hotel. (The Airport Limousine tickets alone is 3,000 yen per person, but if you throw in the Tokyo Metro Pass, and but them as a set, it only cost you 3,100 yen per person. There might be a minimum purchase of 2 sets, though.)

I stayed here for five nights while attending a conference at a nearby university. The staff were very helpful and spoke reasonable English. My room was a superior double on the 17th floor, I had a view of the building opposite with a bit of Tokyo between it and the next building. But even that was amazing from the 17th floor. My room was plenty big enough, with table and chairs, TV, huge comfy bed, big bath, and a fair bit of space to unpack into. Reception provided me with an adapter so that I could plug my laptop etc in, and I had free wifi. Breakfast wasn't incredibly good, but it was incredible, for the weird mix of food on offer including salad and pasta dishes. I'm told the Japanese breakfasts were great, I was happy enough with my eggs and toast, and cereal. The bar in the hotel is quiet but really enjoyable, and the Japanese gentleman I met there told me that the bartender is famous. There is a book of cocktails in the bar, and the barman is in the photo on the back. He makes good margaritas, and there is a large whiskey selection which my friends made headway with. As a solo traveler, I had an enjoyable meal in the restaurant on my first night, that's the last time I had western meals as Japanese food turned out to be amazing. The hotel is really well located, because its only a short walk from four different train lines, and in around Mita there are some great little restaurants, including an outstanding Ramen bar which I would direct you to if only it had an English name. I've try to put a photo of it up, and a map, so you could probably find it if you want an adventure. I had the special dipping Ramen, it was just amazing. The next afternoon we went back for Gyoza, and they were the best dumplings I ever hope to have.

I stayed at the Celestine Hotel in Tokyo for seven days on a business trip. The hotel is located within the central Tokyo area, and easy access from Narita airport via the Airport Express train to Shinagawa Station and a short taxi ride from there. The hotel is located on the 14th-17th floors of a corporate building, with a spacious lobby, café and restaurant on the ground floor. My room, a twin room, was a corner room on the 14th floor with fine views across to the east, and views of Tokyo harbor as well. The room was really spacious, and the daily care of the room was careful and attentive. It was a lovely room, and one that facilitated work with a spacious desk and good internet service. There is a very nice lounge with an outside smoking and non-smoking zone on the 14th floor as well, providing a relaxed area for coffee, tea, water and biscuits which are available throughout the day and evening. It provides wireless internet as well. The Tavern & Grill Grand Cross, located on the ground floor provided an ample selection for breakfast – with a good selection of western, Japanese and vegetarian options. I thought it was fresh, tasty and enough variety over the seven days of stay. The hotel staff were the essence of courtesy, helpfulness and willing to answer any questions with patience and thoughtfulness. The hotel is just a short walk to both Mita and Shibakoen stations on the Mita line. If you are planning to do considerable travelling around, certainly buy a Suica card (at the airport or at any station). This will allow you to move through the multitude of privately owned train lines with ease, and it will let you know when you need to top it up! Otherwise it is a complex and time consuming process of buying endless tickets, and this can be a hassle when you change lines. For the health conscious, the hotel does not have any fitness facilities at all.

This was my first time staying at this hotel although I've been to Tokyo before. Our Japanese business office is located five minutes away.The front desk area was always highly staffed with three or four people ready to assist.My room was on the west side of the building and as others have noted, there was a beautiful view of Mt Fuji in the morning.By western standards, my "superior double" room was not overly spacious, but the space was well engineered. I not only had a double bed, but a coffee table, small loveseat, small desk, closet and trouser press. The bathroom had tons of counter space, and the tub was large enough for me to have a terrific soak one evening.There were a total of seven electric outlets in the room including one right by my bed which I used with my CPAP. None of them had the third grounding prong you see in the US.There is no gym or swimming pool but I did make use of the lounge which as others noted is friendly and inviting. There are drinks for sale in the lounge, but there is no pressure to buy anything, you can just quietly sit and enjoy the area whether inside or out.The hotel is located within a two minute walk of a subway station and a short cab ride from a few larger stations. I walked to the Tokyo Tower and Zojoji Temple, and each is about a 20 minute walk.The neighbourhood is quiet where this hotel is located, and we found ourselves walking some distance or taking the subway or a taxi to dinner. There is a restaurant in the hotel (Grand Cross) and we did eat there on our first night. The Grand Cross is a good restaurant, and I can't complain about it, but also it was not spectacular or particularly notable. We were the only guests in the restaurant on the Monday night that we went.I'll make the Celestine my first choice the next time I'm in Tokyo on business.

Spent 3 nights here at the behest of an international conference held at nearby Keio University. Room was fine, but when I saw a much bigger room with a better view than what I had, I was envious. First time I saw that part of the mirror in the bathroom did not fog up after showering- must have electrical cables behind it. The entire hotel is spotless. Buffet breakfast was wonderful, allowing guests to mix and match Japanese with western items. Staff was extremely helpful in every instance. Especially appreciated the complimentary use of umbrellas. Convenient to several subway lines.

We spent 3 nights in this hotel. the rooms were spacious enough and very comfortable. the staff were always very polite and helpful. Especially the concierge girl. she went out of her way to direct us with things to do and how to get there. we will certainly stay here again.

The location of the hotel is quite convenient for the tourist in Tokyo, though it's geared toward the business traveller. It is located a block away from the Shibakoen metro stop, two blocks to the Mita metro stop, and just a 5 minute further walk to the Tamachi JR (Yamanote) line. The convenience of these three transit options can pretty much get you anywhere within the metro area easily. If arriving from the airport via Narita Express, reserve your seat to get off at Shinagawa, then back-track one stop to Tamachi on the elevated JR Yamanote line (much easier than transfering at the larger, and more confusing, Tokyo station).The lower half of the building is occoupied by offices so the ground floor is divided into an office entrance lobby and the hotel entrance lobby. For a smallish hotel, the lobby is quite large, with two story windows, a coffee/chocolate shop, and a fully attentive staff available 24/7.Hotel rooms are located on floors 14-17. 95% of the rooms face the outside, but 8-10 rooms per floor face an interior courtyard. Rooms facing north and south are much larger, but face other buildings and offer obstructed views. Rooms facing east and west are incredibly small, but provide nice city views. I've been to the hotel twice (2006 and 2011). The first time we had a larger south facing room that was comfortable, but had limited skyline views. Last week we had a west facing room. It is probably one of the tiniest hotel rooms you'll find anywhere, but we were rewarded with two rare mornings where the ever-present haze lifted and we could see Mount Fuji in the distance behind the skyline.Fortunately, they've done everything they could to maximize the tiny space. We had a queen size bed with two wall mounted end tables (barely enough room for an alarm clock and glass of water), a wall mounted desk/mini-bar/TV stand combination, a small, two-person seat that barely fit between the end table and windows, and a small coffee table that could fit a laptop and magazine side-by-side.Near the entry door is a built-in closet/dresser that is so narrow that the hanging rod goes toward you instead of parallel to the wall. We had to double (and triple) up clothes on hangers in layer (pants first, then two shirts on top of them). There are similarly narrow drawers next to it (one wastefully taken up by mini-bar candies and snacks). Although the walkable area of the bathroom was tiny, it did provide lots of counter space and a spacious bath tub. This room provided nice features like a steam-proof section of mirror over the sink and a Toto toilet (the typical Japanese kind with bidet functions and heated seats).The decorations are contemporary and clean in the rooms and in the common areas.There is no gym or pool, but the 14th floor does offer a lounge with complimentary water, coffee, and tea all day long, and some outdoor seating in the courtyard. Don't expect views, though...it's an interior courtyard with 4+ floors of hotel rooms completely surrounding it. We did find it a pleasant space to sit at night, though. Even more surprising, we saw stars despite being in one of the brightest and most crowded cities on earth.The Celestine also has a first floor restaurant called Grand Cross that offers breakfast for about 2,000 yen (currently the equivalent of about $26.00 US). Some room mates include the breakfast and you'll get meal tickets for each morning.As with the hotel lobby staff, the crew here is very attentive. I must admit I find the food options hilarious. In an attempt to accomodate all nationalities, the buffet stations have the standard eggs, bacon, yogurt, fruit, cereal and toast...but also spaghetti, broccolli, hot dogs, tater tots and a few Japanase items (rice, miso soup, tofu). I remind you...these are items served from 7am - 9:30am for breakfast!I found $26 a bit steep so I made the most out of breakfast by going closer to 9:30, eating heartily, then having a smaller lunch later on.The office side of the ground floor also has a restaurant (Itlaian) and, I believe a small Japanese restaurant and a Tully's Coffee Shop.Again, the staff here are incredibly attentive and friendly. At all times, you will find at least 4 or 5 people in the lobby...often rushing to push the button on the elevator for you. They'll gladly loan you an umbrella if it's looking like rain (which is common in Tokyo). One funny side story...my husband is allergic to feather pillows so on our third morning he went to the lobby to request a non-feather pillow. That evening we returned to the room to find two new pillows that were hard as a rock. It felt like clay....you'd get the pillow into position then it would never move. Being the curious type, I inspected further by removing the pillow case and unzipping the pillow. What we found was straw. Not the stuff horses eat, but drinking straws cut into thousands of 1/4 inch pieces.Anyway, this was my second time at the Celestine and I'd definitely stay there again. My husband has probably been there dozens of times on various business trips, too. Neither of us has had a bad experience. The small east and west facing rooms are definitely more comfortable for one person versus two people, but our west-facing view this time was quite spectacular by day and night (we could see Shinjuku and Mount Fuji). But if you're used to western standard room sizes, you may be more comfortable facing south...especially if you'll be staying for more than a few nights.

I've stayed here twice since December 2010. Both times the hotel met my needs perfectly. Beds are comfortable, room is small, but large enough for one person. Wifi works well. Breakfast is perfect for me. I'll stay here again soon.
I have stayed at this hotel, several times and it is one of the best business hotels, very close to my office. Very good service!Would surely stay again!

This was my first stay at this hotel, I was a little hesitated about booking this hotel because of the review I read. But after I checked into the hotel - very clean, friendly and very polite staff, centrally located with subway stations near by, and tons of comvenient shops. About 10 minutes walking distance from the hotel (towards the NEC HQ direction) you will find a restaurant street where there are about 30 big and small restaurants for you to choose, I had a great time there!
Very clean, excellent food, great price. Not a vacation spot but for business on a budget this is an outstanding hotel.

I stayed in a deluxe corner room, which had an excellent view of Tokyo and the bay. The room was very spacious, and the bathroom was one of the best I've ever stayed in--Japanese toilet with special options, of course, but also a shower area with rainforest head and three additional sprays for an all-enveloping shower experience. The service was top-notch and the location is right next to Tokyo Tower (well worth visiting) and right next to a subway stop. The room was very quiet for undisturbed sleep and had nice amenities. Overall, an A+ hotel!

This hotel makes a very good first impression; clean, tidy and professional service. The public rooms are all well presented and outfitted with the amenities you would expect. The price is quite good for downtown Tokyo. The room is normal size for Tokyo, which is small. It really ticked all the boxes and was on its way to getting a fairly spectacular review if it weren't for two little problems that I view as extremely significant....1. The massive cockroach that took over my bathroom and 2. the woman with a severe attitude that checked me out.The cockroach: To be fair, the cockroach probably thought I was gone for the day. I had returned from an early morning meeting and went back up to my room to get ready for the next meeting. Stuck my room card into the slot next to the door to turn on the lights, threw open the bathroom door and turned on the light and there was the biggest cockroach I have ever seen sitting in front of the toilet, and it looked like he was looking at me. I actually had to lean in and wave at him to get him to scurry off. I went back down and asked the people at the reception, quite discreetly, to remove the monster insect from my bathroom. No apologies from the staff just a nod. The next day my colleague changed his room after he had a mini-stampede of two cockroaches running across the desk while he was working on his computer.2. The woman who checked me out: For the management team: It was Saturday September 4th, it was about 6:15 am and the lady who checked me out was working the far right station (when facing the checkout desk). Unfriendly is an understatement - totally different to the rest of the staff that I encountered, all of whom were professional and friendly. Anyway, she did give me my airport bus ticket, but "forgot" to give me my luggage tags - which I didn't know I needed, but I'm guessing she did. When the bus driver refused to load my bag due to missing tags, I ran back in to the hotel and she put up a hand "Please wait". Sorry but the bus was leaving. Fortunately somebody els from the desk staff helped me out and I was able to catch the bus.Other than the cockroach problem that this hotel seems to have, It is a very good hotel. I'm not sure how much they can do about the problem - it's not my field of expertise. All I can say is that this is the first "nice" hotel that I've ever stayed at with this problem and it is a bit disconcerting.

Stayed for a week at the Celestine, Tokyo during biz trip. Great location, very near to Corp. office. Good location within walking distance of Tamachi Station, great rail connectivity. This was very helpful as I had to travel to Odawara by Shinkansen at Shinagawa station. Also, good to catch the Narita Airport Express.There are some good restaurants in the vicinity of Tamachi Stn. and the Tokyo Tower is also nearby.The hotel staff was very attentive and helpful especially for the reqd. power adapter and umbrella as it was constantly raining in Tokyo. Breakfast & internet were part of the package, the room was fine and so was the overall ambience.
Small but design and very confortable rooms, very nice restaurant downstairs, great staff

I stayed at the Celestine hotel in Tokyo for 4 nights in April 2010.The room was quite comfortable, very clean, and with a large window facing the city.The staff were extremely efficient and helpful; breakfast buffet was abundant and full of choices. The lounge in the 14th floor was a good quiet place to unwind after busy working days;few hotels in the world offer this facility.There are metro stations very near by.All in all, the hotel is top quality and rates reasonable.For me this is one of the best choices for anyone going to Tokyo on business or pleasure.

I have stayed at the Celestine about 15 times beginning the first week it was opened - from single nights to 12 day stays. It is quiet, comfortable, has great views (weather pending) and a very attentive and accommodating staff. It is my first choice when visiting this area of Tokyo. The outdoor garden on the 14th floor is one of my favorite places to unwind with casual conversation and a cup of coffee after a long day (or early jet-lagged morning). Dining in the area is good, but not great. There are some nice smaller restaurants across from Tamachi station.

Stayed only for 2 nights, but we were pleasantly surprised. Nothing could be really faulted, except for maybe the slightly older style of bathrooms. Fantastic views of Tokyo as the hotel rooms are at the top of the building. Everything works, very quiet, staff professional, would use as a business hotel as well, and would also shop around for best rates (we used a Japanese site that had the best rates). Only thing to note is that while it is 'centrally' located in Tokyo, it is not on any major road or next to a major station, but as there are subway stops nearby this was not a big problem.

Hi,I stayed in Celestine Hotel , Minato Ku, Tokyo for a week during my business trip to Tokyo. I chose this hotel due to its location & previous good reviews of my colleagues.Positives:Excellent location - 2 Railway lines run very close to the hotel. You can reach any destination in Tokyo within sometimeWalking distance to Tokyo tower & other attractionsExcellent customer serviceBreakfast - The spread was real good. Dont miss the Fish.The Roof top Japanese Garden is very unique for this hotel.Negatives:I dont remember any

Stayed for a week in October on business. Very attentive staff and I suggest you follow their recommendations for local dining. I did eat in the attached restaurant once, but ventured out after that.The room was small - even by Tokyo standards - but clean and the view of Fujii one morning was spectacular. The queen sized bed was comfortable, the mini bar adequate, bathroom rather small. I use it because it is close to the office - for any other trip, I'd be looking for something closer to the night life.

I stayed in the Deluxe Corner King room for 6 nights.Deluxe Corner Room: I strongly recommend this room category. The room is very spacious, while most hotel rooms in Tokyo are very small. The king size bed was very comfortable and very clean. The bathroom is so spacious and beautiful that you can enjoy taking shower there every day.If you book the corner room, you get upgraded bathroom amenities such as organic lotion.The only complain is that the room was a little dusty. Breakfast: My plan came with the breakfast. The breakfast buffet has both american and japanese food, which was very nice. Especially the Japanese menu was very healthy and delicious.Location: it is in the middle of metro area. Tokyo tower and subway stations are a step away.Overall, I strongly recommend this hotel for either business trip, sightseeing or romantic getaway.

Very nice hotel. The company booked us 5 nights there and I love this hotel very much. Though room is a little small but it was very comfortable. There's a cozy lounge where you can have your meetings or discussion. Not many retail or entertainment facilities around. I guess that is because it is a business district. The hotel provides very generous amount of toiletries as well as tea/coffee bags. Breakfast is nothing to shout about.

I loved this hotel. It was clean, modern, quiet. Upon entering the ground floor to the reception desk there is a small but pleasant dining area, and an automated piano playing soft classical music.Every morning I had a free english-language paper put outside my door - I didn't request this and was a lovely extra.The free Ethernet connection worked perfectly (don't forget to bring an Ethernet cable to Japan). The availability of the free-to-use safe was welcome. The television worked well although the channels are in Japanese.Near the reception desk there is a pay phone and phone cards are available - I didn't realise at the time there are two types of phone cards available, domestic and international, and I needed the assistance of a receptionist to point out the difference. The reception staff were very helpful although I was doing my best to communicate in limited Japanese.This was my second visit to Tokyo and was the last good hotel available for the weekend I arrived, I stayed for seven days with no complaints!I was staying during the last week of March - cherry blossom season. It was a cool (warm jackets essential) but pleasant time of year.Location wise this wasn't the easiest hotel to get to. I took the Narita Express from Narita Airport to Tokyo station, then changed lines and took the Yamanote JR line to Tamachi station, where I walked to the hotel (about a 10 minute walk). Mita underground station is closer but I was using a Japan Rail Pass and wanted to only use the JR lines.The area is safe enough, I returned to the hotel on foot a few times at around 3 or 4 in the morning. I cannot say the same about Rappongi where a group of Nigerians physically assaulted me because of my (white) skin colour.There are some nice cafes between the hotel and Tamachi JR station.Overall I highly recommend this hotel and would return again.

December was my most recent of about 8 stays at the Celestine. My visits have lasted from three days to eight days. My first stay there was shortly after they opened, and I can say that the quality of rooms, service and breakfast has not faltered at all. It is a simple, low-key hotel by Tokyo standards, which I appreciate -- there are not lots of people bowing as you enter, running to the elevator to push the button for you. Instead it has an under-stated, professional and cordial staff, ready to help in any way possible. I enjoy the buffet breakfast, which offers both western and Japanese choices. There is no reason to eat lunch or dinner in the hotel.I have stayed at many hotels in Tokyo, and this is by far the quietest. In fact, I have never heard any noise from the rooms, which are located on the top floors of an office building. The location may seem a bit out of the way, but as a previous reviewer wrote, it is a five minute walk to the Mita Subway Station and only a few minutes further to the Tamachi JR Station, so you can get anywhere in Tokyo very quickly, then return to the peace and quiet of the Celestine. The rooms are a good size for Japan, and very comfortable. I should warn you that the mattresses are very firm, but you will find this nearly everywhere in the country (historically, their standard is a futon on the floor). You will have everything you need -- television with CNN and BBC, high speed internet access, and robes, towels and toiletries replaced daily.My only complaint is that it is a long ride on the Limousine Bus to and from the airport, because there are a number of other stops, which are not necessarily on the way. You can take the Narita Express train to Shinagawa Station, which is not far from the Celestine, then take a taxi to the hotel, but this is inconvenient with luggage. I will likely stay here again many times in the future, and I will do so happily.

I was on business here and although couldn't find many reviews decided to give it a go! It was a great location for what I wanted, it's not too far from the Tokyo Tower. It is quite a new hotel, the rooms were a good size for Japan and had flat screen TV, mini bar and free coffee/tea - also a lounge on 14th floor with free soft drinks all day. The bathroom was good too, very powerful shower. The staff were very friendly and happy to advise anything. The Mita subway station is nearby (5 min walk) and is so efficient. Breakfast and dinner is good. Would definitely recommend - even though no swimming pool or gym.

I stayed in this hotel for a few days while sightseeing in Tokyo. The hotel is located in the Shiba area, right next to the NEC building and close to the Tokyo Tower. It is clean, and modern, and the reception staff are polite and fluent in English. The rooms are located on the upper three floors of the building, and the reception is on the ground floor. The hotel is clearly intended for business travellers, though it is also suitable for tourists given its central location. However, families with children will definitely feel out of place and would probably be better served elsewhere. The rooms are on the small side, but reasonably sized for central Tokyo, and they are fully featured, e.g. minibar, bath, safe, cable TV, and free Internet. There is a dining/bar area, and free drinks are provided in the reception area. The hotel is quiet inside, and the rooms are secure and kept immaculately clean. The area immediately surrounding the hotel is mainly business establishments and is perfectly safe to walk around after dark. If you walk a short way towards the nearby university you will find a range of shops and a selection of excellent restaurants. The hotel is around 5 minutes walk from the Tamachi JR station (Yamanote line), and is also very close to the Mita subway station (Mita and Asakusa lines). These stations allow you direct access all of the important areas in central Tokyo, e.g. Shinagawa, Ginza, Asakusa, and Ueno. To reach the hotel from the main Airport (Narita) you will want to take the airport train service to Tokyo station, and then the JR line to Tamachi station - this takes around 1.5 hours so you will need to leave plenty of time. To reach the hotel from the domestic airport (Haneda), you take the monorail to Hamamatsucho station and then the JR line for one stop to Tamachi station - this takes around a half hour. Do not take a taxi to/from the airport unless you are willing to spend a lot of money! In summary, this is an excellent hotel in central Tokyo that is geared primarily towards western business travellers. It is well connected to the transport system, and my stay there was pleasant and problem free.
